Changes from Drupal 7


Field collection


Fields in field collection have converted to Paragraphs type in D8. 


In Basic page type, the sidebar field collection now are in Paragraphs sidebar blocks.


Menu link attributs




Menu attributs modules is no longer use and in favor of link attributes module.




Access Control




In D7, there
s opion to allow the vacaburary be one of the active editorial section (admin/structure/taxonomy/access_control/edit). This option is not longer available in D8.




Node clone module




There
s no D8 version of this, and will not be migrated. 




Page class




In D7, the context module add a classname to the body tag based on the path. This no longer the case in D8. There
s a custom implementation to accomplish the same. Look at the add_classname_based_on_path() in nyulaw.theme. In addition, now page can specify its own class name via layout option.




Related link/Super header block




This used to be created by Views, but now we can just create a block directly thanks for the Field API.

Define the problem






Web site performance suffers due to out-dated infrastructure software




Current platform is running on AWS EC2 Ubuntu 12.04.5 LTS with PHP 5.3.  


Ubuntu 12.04.5 end of life support on April 28, 2017. Upgrade asap is critial.  


PHP 5.3 end of life support on Aug 14 2014.  


Drupal 7 minimum recommended PHP5.4. Drupal 8 recommended PHP 7.2.








Web site is not able to handle HTTPS traffics




Some content has hardcode http links.


Infrastructure set up is not able to direct HTTPS traffic correctly.


LDAP or oAuth authentication is not possible 








Complex infrastructure setup with redirect, load balancers, vanish




Difficult to debug when problem occurs. 


True client IP can not detected resulting users got blocked from login.








Server recently become very fragile and slow




Deploying code could bring server down when cache clear


Logged in editors suffer longer delay when editing content for unknown reason








Deployment requires many coordination




Webteam is not able to deploy to staging and live environment and has to rely on other person who has greater priviledge, which makes deployment very inflexible.








Isolation for testing new feature is cumbersome






Limited access and total control




When something goes wrong, webteam may not be able to pingpoint the problem quickly due to limit access and deploy quick fix to the problem.








Lack of information on how the entire infrastructure is set up




No one within the webteam oversea the entire system.


No one within the webteam understand the infrastructure and integration.








Lack of Drupal expert support at the infrastructure level






Disaster recovery (rollback) strategy is unclear






Identify the criteria




Performance - how the site performce under heavy load


Scalability - can the site scale up/down to meet demand


Stability - how the site can stay up without service interruption


Technical support at speedy fashion - how easy to reach expert support


Multi dev support - how easy to spin up a new test environment


Ease of deployment - how easy to deploy new change to production


Ease of data migration - moving data from one envioment to another


Customization - deployment hook, seperate configuration per env etc


Log analysis - any utility for monitor site traffics and logs


Intergration (oAth, Coldfusion, splunk etc)


User management - How easy to set up account to allow users have different level of access (External, Internal)


Backup and Disaster recovery - how easy/quickly to recovery


Cost - How much it will cost to run the stack


Server attack mitigation - how to avoid/mitigate server attack such as Ddos, brute force login attempt etc.


Data protection and privacy - how data is store and treat, who can access the data


Storage capacity (See 
https://pantheon.io/docs/platform-considerations/#highly-populated-directories
)


Development tooling - Utility to assist develpment/management


Complexity - how easy to use the platform


Peace of mind/stress - how much support the platform provider can provide


Github/CI integration 


Limitation on modules use


Standard Drupal distribution (no alteration of core)


Other CMS support


Custom upstream - provide a custom bootstrap standard site


Technical support resource 


Email service - SMTP server


Media Streaming


Dev site protection (password) - how easy to set up basic protection for a dev site


Dealing with large file delivery (
 50mb)


Static IP - ability to bind a site to a static IP


Nginx/Apache, customization for server config


Migrating the current site to another platform 


Environment consistency - configure environment with the same set up 


Git based source control


Security on platform - how well the platform protect against intrusion




Weight the criteria


Generate alternative




K8 on AWS


Pantheon


Acquia




Rate alternative on the criteria


Rank each criteria 1 - 5 (1 is the lowest; 5 is the heighest)




Ease of deployment


K8 (2)
* Since there no intuitive UI interface, deployment most likely will utilize commandline interface. Less tech savvy users may found it difficult to use or have a steeper learning curve.
* Permission set up for users may also less straight foward.
* If something goes wrong, rollback could also be complicated.
* It is not sure at this point the webteam will have fully access for deployment, which is a higly desirable feature.


Pantheon (5)
* It provides a simple use UI that allow site admin to deploy from one environment to another.
* With 
EDU plan
, user role with various permission could be set up via the UI.
* Backup can be schecule nightly/manually, if something mess up, rollback could be easily done.


Acquia
* TBD

docs.text: Primary migration will divide into 3 phrases: migrate site structures from source site; modify site structure based on new needs; migrate content from source site.   Run migration to generate structure based on the Source Site  After the structures is generated, modified it base on the need of the new site. Also make sure the machine name is mapped to the old type field name.  Make sure to export all the configs as code  drush config-export -y . This will save all the config in the ../config directory  Start content migration    Use the  Config Installer  to import site profile is the easiest way for manage site structure   Once the site structure is ready, use  drush config-export -y  to export entire site configs  Install Drupal as usual, but using the minimal profile  Run  fin drush site-install --verbose config_installer config_installer_sync_configure_form.sync_directory=../config --yes  to re-install the site based on config files in the sync directory  Once it is completed, the srceen will show the user name and password. In case that is not working, Use  fin drush upwd admin --password= admin  to reset admin password

Core/Module update


The site uses composer as package manger to manage core/module update. Generally, you will use the following commands:


# To find out what are out-of-date
composer outdate

# To update a module
composer update [module_name]

or

composer update [module_name]:[specific version using sematnic versioning syntax]


# Run update script
cd [drupal_root]
drush updatedb




Update Drupal Core


composer update drupal/core

# Sometimes drupal/core update is not update, use following to check what is blocking the update.
composer prohibits drupal/core:8.5.0 // version number




Update drupal-core-restrict


Once the core is updated, run 

composer require 
drupal/drupal-core-restrict:[the exact drupal version]




To learn more about composer with syntax for versioning, take a look at 
Drupal 8 Composer Best Practices
.


Composer install vs. Composer update


Never run composer update in production. Correct workflow should be: 
1. Run Composer update in dev to generate the composer.lock file 
2. Run composer install in prod based on composer.lock




See: 
composer update
 vs 
composer install


What is the drupal-core-restrict package in composer.json


From: 
https://www.previousnext.com.au/blog/using-composer-debug-issues-updating-drupal-core




Quote


running composer update 
drupal/core
 
with-dependencies is in general not something that you want to do on your
Drupal site. The reason is that the Drupal core developers only update Drupal’s dependencies on minor releases –
e.g. from 8.3.x to 8.4.0. If you use composer update to get a newer patch release of Drupal core, then you will end
up with a different set of dependencies than Drupal is currently using. While this should, in general work, your
configuration will not be exactly the same as the one that the core committers are testing, so you become more
likely to encounter new dependency bugs before the rest of the community. If your goal is to update a site that is
in production, this is generally not what you want.


To work around this problem, try using 
https://github.com/webflo/drupal-core-strict
. This project contains tagged
releases that strongly constrain the versions of all of Drupal’s dependencies to match what is being tested in
Drupal core. If you require this project in your Composer-managed Drupal site, then you will be able to use
composer update to update your non-Drupal-core-releated dependencies without bringing in more updates than
intended.


For additional background on phpdocumentor version constraints and Drush, see

https://github.com/drush-ops/drush/pull/2877




Resource


- [Using Composer to efficiently govern your core, module, and patch updates](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=c6iV-Q-i7gg
amp;index=32)
- [Composer Stability Flags](https://igor.io/2013/02/07/composer-stability-flags.html)
